title: humans do replay events waking hours sleep scientists conclude
story: Scientists have proved for the first time that humans replay events from their waking hours as they sleep - and that dreaming is a crucial part of how we form memories.In a groundbreaking study, researchers were able to watch people playing out what had happened in their day, with their brains mimicking the same neuronal firing patterns as those exhibited before they went to bed.This is the first direct evidence that we relive real-life experiences in our sleep, and could help explain how memories are consolidated in the mind.The process had previously been observed in animals, but brain imaging techniques have so far not been advanced enough to test the theory on humans.The study, published in the journal Cell Reports, was a collaboration between Massachusetts General Hospital in the US and the company Braingate, which is developing technology to restore the communication, mobility, and independence of people with neurologic disease, injury, or limb loss.Dr Beata Jarosiewicz, a senior research scientist from BrainGate, said: This is the first piece of direct evidence that in humans, we also see replay during rest following learning that might help to consolidate those memories.The study is unprecedented. All the replay-related memory consolidation mechanisms that we've studied in animals for all these decades might actually generalise to humans as well.The study involved monitoring the brain activity of two people with tetraplegia - a condition which results in partial or full paralysis of all four limbs.These subjects were chosen as they already had implants inserted in the motor cortex of their brains as part of their treatment. The implants allow them to move a cursor on a screen just by thinking about it.The researchers fitted the pair with electrodes to record their brain activity then asked them to move the cursor in a series of patterns, some of which they were told to repeat many times.The participants then went to sleep for 30 minutes with the electrodes still monitoring their neuronal firing patterns - the communication between neurones in the brain.While the subjects were asleep, the neuronal firing patterns they had exhibited when they were awake and moving the cursor were re-performed by their brains so often that the scientists concluded this was not mere coincidence.The hippocampus, the part of the brain responsible for memory and learning, appeared to have taken a snapshot of their waking brain patterns then reactivated them later during sleep to make the memory permanent.Dr Jarosiewicz said the study shows that sleep is a vital part of how we learn.We have good scientific evidence that sleep is very important in these processes, she said. There is still much we don't understand about sleep, but it is clear that it is important for the brain.Further research is now needed to better understand exactly what phase of sleep best triggers this kind of replay mechanism, and whether the strength of this replay mechanism might be altered to improve memory and learning.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: inside story princesses elizabeth margaret celebrated ve day
story: According to the adage, usually attributed to Winston Churchill, history is written by the victors. But what happens when there are multiple accounts?During the time I spent researching A Royal Night Out – the 2015 film I co-wrote with Kevin Hood – this quickly became a recurring question.The film dramatises how 19-year-old Princess Elizabeth (played by Emily Watson) and her sister, 15-year-old Princess Margaret (Sarah Gadon), spent VE Day on May 8, 1945. But whose account of their adventure – and there are many… – is closest to what actually happened that night?The story of the princesses secretly taking part in the VE Day celebrations had lain dormant for years, until the incident was touched upon by the BBC as a footnote to a piece on the 60th anniversary of the end of the war. This item then came to the attention of film producers Ecosse Films and Lionsgate, who thought the princesses out on the town celebrating incognito could make a great movie. As a result, I was approached about developing this half-forgotten historical snippet into a screenplay.Although the tale we tell is clearly a work of imagination, rooting our story in truth was important. But whose truth?I read royal biographies and wartime social histories until my eyes hurt. In each account, the Princesses’ VE night celebrations would usually merit a paragraph or two, but even here the writers were drawing on different sources. I dug out old footage of TV shows featuring, mostly, Ladies-in-Waiting, who professed to having actually being there on the night. Yet no two accounts were ever the same.One account claimed that the Princesses left Buckingham Palace, crossed Green Park, arms linked, 40 abreast with a large number of other revellers, all of whom came from the royal palace. Some quoted more modest numbers – 12 or so courtesans accompanying the Princesses down Whitehall and on to The Mall, where they watched their parents on the balcony of Buckingham Palace.Other accounts suggest that the Princesses went out accompanied by a small group of friends, with just a couple of officers to keep an eye on them. One even has Princess Elizabeth dancing a jig with a sailor until disengaged by her chaperone. Some maintain Princess Elizabeth wore her ATM uniform, while others suggest she was in civvies.Among all these conflicting stories, one of the few consistencies was that the Princesses visited The Ritz that night, where they danced the conga.The Princess’s governess Marion Crawford, better known as Nannie Crawford, was another interesting source. Her book The Little Princesses, a 1950s bestseller, touched upon the event: The King allowed his two daughters to go out of the gates and among the crowds. Two Guards officers took them, and they joined the revellers outside, and called with the rest, for the King and Queen to come out.Maureen Waller’s excellent portrait of the final months of the war, London 1945, quotes Robert Westall’s Children of the Blitz, which in turn recounts, 50 years on, Queen Elizabeth’s own recollection: “We cheered the King and Queen on the balcony and then walked miles through the streets. I remember lines of unknown people linking arms and walking down Whitehall, all of us just swept along on a tide of happiness and relief… I think it was one of the most memorable nights of my life.”The film website imdb, in its entry about A Royal Night Out, suggests the plot is based on extracts from the Queen’s “diary” (not a text I’ve ever come across…): “Trafalgar Square, Piccadilly, Pall Mall, walked simply miles. Saw parents on balcony at 12.30am – ate, partied, bed 3am!”Perhaps such variations are to be expected. After all, memories fade and, over time, accounts become embellished or tweaked to serve the teller. One person’s half-truth becomes gospel, especially when committed to print, and before you know it, urban myth becomes accepted reality.So who to believe?In the end, the film itself made the decisions. I was commissioned to write the princesses’ story as a screwball comedy, in the style of classic black-and-white romances involving themes of escape and disguise such as It Happened One Night, Bringing Up Baby and His Girl Friday. Typically, in these films, an upper-class female lead and a male character hailing from a much humbler background are thrown together after a cute chance meeting.So, in A Royal Night Out we paired the future Queen of England, out with her sister incognito, with a low-ranking airman and had them meeting for the first time upstairs on a double-decker bus where, embarrassingly, Elizabeth has no money for her fare.Now we knew the general direction of the movie, we cherry-picked the accounts that best served the story. Deferring to Nannie Crawford, we had two Guards Officers as incompetent chaperones, who were also useful for comic relief. We took Elizabeth and Margaret to The Ritz and had them dancing the conga, as suggested by several accounts, and we also incorporated a scene where the Princesses are outside the Palace waving at their parents on the balcony. Beyond these elements, the rest of the movie is a work of imagination and invention.Of course, filmmakers have always played fast and loose with the truth. Obscure, little-known facts become launchpads for entire movies. Timelines are stretched or squashed. Multiple characters are combined into a single composite or sometimes culled altogether for the sake of brevity. This is the nature of nature story-telling. Indeed, producers have to be creative to deliver a movie and we were no different. It’s just another sleight of hand.Take, for example, the locations used by A Royal Night Out. Chatsworth House and Belvoir Castle double for the interiors of Buckingham Palace. Hull stands in for the streets (and pubs) of London the Hotel pole in Brussels stood in for The Ritz.That said, one of the biggest scenes in the film which takes place in Trafalgar Square as Big Ben chimes midnight, signalling the start of peacetime, was actually shot in Trafalgar Square. How do we know this is true? Because I was there that night. You have my word!A final point. Although the quote about history being written by the victors is attributed to Churchill, a quick Google search suggests otherwise. Ironically, Hermann Göring is reported at having said it during the Nuremburg trials – and, going back further still, so too did Maximilien Robespierre.Clearly, it is hard to uncover absolute truth, especially when there are so many versions. Which perhaps lends credence to the whispered suggestion that the story of Elizabeth and Margaret escaping the palace for one night of adventure was actually invented by some bright spark at the Ministry of Information as a feel-good PR stunt.Now that would be a story…A Royal Night Out is available to watch on Amazon Prime and other selected streaming servicesMore from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: jersey poised launch lockdown exit strategy can uk learn islanders
story: Jersey has launched a detailed four-point exit strategy to return life to normal, in what could provide a blueprint for how Britain lifts its own lockdown.From next week, residents will be allowed to meet and socialise with up to five friends and relatives, as the controlled lifting of the current restrictions begins.Officials on the island, who have been in charge of their own Covid-19 response, have set out and published a detailed strategy covering all aspects of public life.The four-stage plan explains to its 100,000 residents how they can expect to see life return to normal in the weeks ahead.Jersey, the largest of the Channel Islands, is currently at Level 4 of its exit strategy, which maintains the stay at home policy, keeps school and colleges closed and prevents large scale gatherings.But on Tuesday, Jersey’s Chief Minister, John Le Fondré Jr, is expected to announce a move to Level 3, described as a ‘soft lockdown’, which will dramatically ease restrictions.The stay at home order will be formally lifted and there will be no restrictions on the amount of time people can spend outside.While social distancing of two metres will still be required, residents will be permitted to spend time with up to five people from outside their household.Schools and colleges on the island will remain closed until May 22, but more children of key workers will be offered places during this period as they attempt to achieve full opening before the summer term ends.All outdoor work will resume and groups of five people will be allowed to operate together on building sites and other premises.Non-essential shops will be given the green light to open and restaurants and cafes with outdoor spaces will be allowed to start serving again.Office based businesses will be encouraged to continue allowing staff to work from home where possible, they will be permitted to let workers return in stages.The plans are thought to go further than what Boris Johnson will announce on Sunday and if successful will allow Jersey to quickly move towards Level 2, or ‘soft opening’ which could come before the beginning of June.That stage will allow gatherings of up to ten people, and should also see the opening of schools and colleges on the island.Healthcare and dental practices will reopen and pubs and bars that serve food will also be given the green light, although they will be asked to operate a reservation only service initially.Level 2 will also see libraries, community centres, youth centres, places of worship, museums and galleries, cinemas, theatres and concert venues, reopen, subject to social distancing rules.The final strand of the exit framework is known as Level 1, or ‘physical distancing’, will signal a move towards some degree of normality in Jersey.Islanders will be allowed to mix with groups of up to 25, and sporting events will be allowed to resume without spectators.Groups of up to 10 people will be allowed to meet inside and working from home will also be phased out.Pubs on the island will be allowed to reopen but customers will be required to sit down at spaced tables, to maintain strict social distancing. Venues will also be required to close by 10pm.Hotels, self-catering accommodation, caravan parks and campsites will also be allowed to reopen subject to guidelines and people will be allowed to travel to and from the island for the first time.Throughout all the four levels of Jersey’s exit strategy, social distancing of two metres will be required and locals will also be encouraged to wear cloth masks when out in the public.Announcing a move towards a soft lockdown next week, Mr Le Fondré told islanders: “Since Saturday, people have been enjoying their four hours permitted outside their homes, but have been doing so in a responsible way that limits the spread of Covid-19. “Because of your actions, we are in a really good place. We’ve seen a minimal increase in the number of positive cases we’ve begun our antibody testing programme and enhanced contract tracing and the Nightingale Hospital has been handed over to medical staff.“We can now look carefully at how we will move through the levels of our Safe Exit Framework. Our expectation is that we will move into Level 3 from the beginning of next week.”While Jersey’s detailed exit strategy could provide ministers in Westminster with a guide to the mainland’s approach, the island has had relatively few coronavirus cases.According to the latest data, Jersey has had 293 confirmed cases and 25 deaths.The island’s lockdown was introduced on March 30, a week after Boris Johnson announced the UK strategy.But with a smaller population and restrictions on travel, the lockdown was less stringent, with residents allowed to exercise for two hours a day. That was increased to four hours last Saturday and locals have also been allowed to visit anywhere on the island in order to take their exercise.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Agreement to unlock £10bn investment in UK over five years once completed, says Virgin Media ownerVirgin Media and O2&nbspare to merge to create a £31bn&nbspmedia and telecoms giant, their parent companies announced on Thursday.The merger is expected to be complete by next year, as it is subject to regulatory clearances.Liberty Global, the US media firm that owns TV and broadband provider Virgin Media, said the agreement would unlock a £10bn investment in the UK market over five years once completed.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMike Fries, CEO&nbspof Liberty Global, said: “We couldn’t be more excited about this combination. Virgin Media has redefined broadband and entertainment in the UK with lightning fast speeds and the most innovative video platform.“And O2 is widely recognised as the most reliable and admired mobile operator in the UK, always putting the customer first.”How to improve your internet connection during lockdownO2 and Virgin Media in merger talks to create telecoms giant Virgin Media says it has fixed issue that left people without internetJose Maria Alvarez-Pallete, CEO of O2 owner Telefonica, said: “Combining O2’s number one mobile business with Virgin Media’s superfast broadband network and entertainment services will be a game changer in the UK, at a time when demand for connectivity has never been greater or more critical.“We are creating a strong competitor with significant scale and financial strength to invest in UK digital infrastructure and give millions of consumer, business and public sector customers more choice and value.”Telefonica confirmed it was in talks with Liberty Global about a merger on Monday.O2 is the UK’s largest mobile phone operator and joining forces with Virgin Media would create an even bigger rival for BT, which owns the UK’s second-largest network EE. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Feature is available on the Google app for iOS and the Google Lens app for AndroidGoogle Lens, the search giant’s artificially-intelligent camera that can recognise objects, has had an upgrade: users can now copy text from the real world and paste it directly onto their laptop.Before this update, Lens was able to copy text captured by the camera to the smartphone, but now it can be linked to any computer with Chrome – whether those are typed words, or handwritten ones.“Now, when you select text with Lens, you can tap ‘copy to computer’ to quickly paste it on another signed-in device with Chrome. This is great for quickly copying handwritten notes (if you write neatly!) and pasting it on your laptop without having to retype them all”, Google said on its blog.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHowever, for&nbspthe copy-and-paste functionality to work properly, users must be using the latest version of the Google Chrome browser, and must be signed in to their Google account on both devices.Lens has improved its foreign language capabilities too users will now be able to select the text with Lens and tap a new Listen button to hear it out loud.Best phone to buy 2020: The latest iPhone, Android and Sony releasesFinally, Google has also added the ability to look up new definitions using Lens. Selecting a word or phrase in a book or newspaper via Lens will bring up a pop-up box with information about the selected word.All of these features are available on&nbspiOS&nbspdevices such as the&nbspiPhone 11&nbspand the&nbspiPad Pro, and Android devices, via the Google app on&nbspiOS&nbspand the separate Google Lens application on Android.Some Android phones, such as Google’s&nbspPixel 4, have the Lens functionality built directly into the primary camera application without needing to download it. Others, such as the&nbspOppo Find X2 Pro, will require the app to be downloaded before it can be found under the “More” section of its main camera app.As well as those mentioned above, Google Lens can also be used to identify plants and animals, to pull up facts about landmarks around you, scanning clothing and furniture, and reading QR codes and barcodes.Google’s Lens functionality was first introduced in 2017 as a part of Google IO.&nbspThe app uses artificial intelligence and machine learning to detect what is in an image by comparing it to a dataset of countless other versions of a similar image.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: supermoon 2020 flower full moon when time watch how
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Good weather and low air pollution makes Thursday a great opportunity to witness the celestial event in the UKThis week's full moon will be the final supermoon of 2020, whereby it appears bigger and brighter than usual in the night's sky.The rare spectacle takes place when the moon is near to its closest point in its orbit, with May's full moon passing at 361,184km&nbspfrom Earth.May's moon is traditionally known as the flower moon, as it coincides with spring blossoms in the northern hemisphere.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesClear skies and unusually low air pollution resulting from the coronavirus lockdown&nbspmakes it a good opportunity for sky gazers in the UK to witness the celestial event.The best time to see it will be after sunset on Thursday evening, when the moon will rise in the south-east at around 8.44pm in the UK.How to take the perfect picture of the supermoonTechnically the exact moment of full moon is 11.45am, however the moon will not be visible in the sky in the UK at that time, said Greg Brown, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory.Times for moonrise and set vary slightly across the UK, but not by more than about 10 minutes or so.Created with Sketch.Pink supermoon lights up the night sky: In pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.An effect called the Moon Illusion means that the moon will appear even bigger at moonrise when it is close to the horizon.This is because the brain is tricked into thinking it is much closer than it actually is, due to its relative size to objects like trees and buildings on the horizon.It will be the final supermoon&nbspuntil April 2021.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: tesla reopen california factory coronavirus lockdown guidelines
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Californian regulations, which have remained in place since March,&nbspforbid the 'manufacturing or assembly of nonessential products'Tesla&nbspmay be planning to reopen the company’s car production plant in Fremont, California, which may violate the state’s coronavirus regulations.According to someone familiar with factory operations, speaking to the San Francisco Chronicle under the condition of anonymity, workers returned to the plant on Wednesday to prepare it for reopening next week.Additional measures have reportedly been put in place to protect against spreading the coronavirus. Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment from The Independent.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe report follows comments made by Tesla CEO Elon Musk, who has consistently denounced&nbspthe lockdown&nbspin the United States. The US has more confirmed&nbspcoronavirus cases than any other country in the world,&nbsprecently topping one million.Mr Musk said the lockdown was “fascist” and demanded authorities “give people back their goddamn freedom”.Elon Musk tweet about 'too high' share price sees Tesla plummet $14bn“I would call it ‘forcibly imprisoning people in their homes’ against all their constitutional rights, in my opinion, and breaking people’s freedoms in ways that are horrible and wrong and not why people came to America or built this country,” Mr Musk also said in a call last week.However, despite the potential for the plant to re-open, a spokesperson for the Fremont Police Department said there were no plans to investigate the site.“We’re all sort of in a little bit of a grey area,” said department spokesperson Geneva Bosques. This is because of the state governor's announcement that some business would be allowed to operate on a small scale if adequate safety measures were taken.Two previous visits were made to the plant, Mr Bosques said, where it was found that Tesla was following basic minimum operations.It would not be the first time that Tesla has defied shelter-in-place orders. The company insisted workers continue for a week after 17 March, when the conditions were put in place, even though the plant was deemed non-essential by health authorities. title: coronavirus help the hungry meals vegan animals plant based london
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Help the Hungry exclusive: ‘We hope the $100,000 of food will help relieve suffering from Covid-19 but the real value of our work lies in telling people how and why pandemics emerge’A group that promotes awareness of the environmental risks of animal consumption is spending $100,000 (£80,000) distributing thousands of vegan meals to vulnerable families in London and abroad during the pandemic.Million Dollar Vegan, which challenged the Pope and Donald Trump to go vegan for a month in return for a $1m donation to charity, has teamed up with an east London charity to provide 3,800 plant-based meals to some of the area’s most needy people to spare them from hunger.The charity had already had so many applicants for food that it had been forced to turn people away.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Now, with our support, they can significantly increase their output, and offer an additional 3,800 meals, which will mean they can feed a lot more families and for longer,” said a spokesperson for Million Dollar Vegan (MDV).The Independent’s&nbspHelp The Hungry campaign is highlighting the UK’s hunger crisis to help those who cannot afford supplies during the coronavirus lockdown.How to support our campaignA survey by YouGov has indicated up to 350,000 people have gone hungry at times during the lockdown because there wasn’t enough food.MDV is also working in nine other countries, including Italy, where distributors are giving out 1,000 vegan meals to patients on Covid-19 wards at a Turin hospital.In Argentina, they have put together 7,000 “ethical aid” packages consisting of meals, hand sanitisers and masks, and are handing them out in the most deprived neighbourhoods of Buenos Aires.MDV was established to raise awareness of how the rearing and consumption of animals “affects the environment, both farmed and wild animals, and human health — including the global risks of zoonotic diseases and antibiotic resistance”.Timeline of viruses humans caught by interacting with animalsIt says the initiative, called #TakePandemicsOffTheMenu, combines a charitable effort with an education campaign to help the world avoid another pandemic.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe London meals are prepared in Hackney and delivered by bike around the area.In France, MDV is giving out 1,200 vegan bowls from a Paris restaurant to homeless people and caregivers in the city’s hospitals, and in Spain it is providing food to frontline care workers in Madrid hospitals.About 6,400 vegan meals will be provided to those in need in Mexico, and about 3,000 in Brazil. In Los Angeles, US, 700 food packages will go to homeless military veterans. Other projects are in India and Ethiopia.How we treat animals ‘still risking spreading disease’Naomi Hallum, director of the organisation, which is funded by donations, said: “We hope that the $100,000 of food we are giving will help relieve some of the suffering caused by Covid-19, but the real value of our work lies in education, in telling people how and why these pandemics emerge, in showing the destruction caused to our planet and our bodies when we eat animal products.“The coronavirus pandemic, like many others before it, is creating tragedies for families all over the world. None of us wants this to happen ever again but to prevent future outbreaks, there are some difficult lessons we must learn.“If we continue to stress wild animals by decimating their habitats and capture and cage them in markets — and if we continue to mass produce domesticated animals inside squalid factory farms and transport them long distances — there will be no avoiding a future pandemic.”T Colin Campbell, professor emeritus of nutritional biochemistry at Cornell University, New York, claimed: “A wholefoods plant-based diet can prevent, perhaps even reverse, the chronic degenerative diseases that make older iniduals more susceptible to Covid-19.”Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus uk private renters evictions lockdown shelter housing allowance
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Thousands struggling to meet costs of rent after losing jobs, says ShelterThousands of private renters who have been forced out of work are facing a “tsunami of evictions” once the coronavirus lockdown is lifted, a housing and homelessness charity has warned.Shelter says many of the two million people applying for universal credit, which includes the local housing allowance, are still struggling to meet the costs of rent.With people unable to safely move to cheaper accommodation, leaving them vulnerable to mounting debt and rent arrears, the charity is calling on the government to further increase housing benefits to match 50 per cent of the average rent in an area.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAt the moment, payments only cover the lowest third of market rents in an area, meaning thousands are facing a large shortfall. For families in a two-bedroom home, the shortfall is as high as £400 a month outside of London, and up to £1,227 in the capital.Shelter says that those relying on benefits must find an estimated £13m a week in total to keep up with their rent payments.How to help the elderly and vulnerable during the coronavirusHow to feel less anxious about the coronavirusHow to be productive when working from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsThe government has suspended evictions for the duration of the crisis, but thousands could be forced out of their homes when the lockdown ends.Polly Neate, chief executive at Shelter, has warned of a “tsunami of evictions” amid the “serious financial difficulty” that people across the country are now facing.“As renters lose their jobs and see their incomes hit, many will have to rely on the welfare safety net for the first time,” she said.“Our services are already hearing from families in homes they could comfortably afford under normal circumstances, who are now in serious financial difficulty.“We’re facing an onslaught of people suddenly unable to afford their rent, at a time when people need to stay put and cannot safely move to a cheaper home.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“To avoid spiralling debt and needless evictions once the ban lifts, the government must increase the housing element of universal credit so that it covers the average cost of local rents.”Emma and her partner, who live in Manchester, have both lost their jobs as a result of the pandemic and, along with thousands of others across the country, are now struggling to pay rent.“Both myself and my partner have now lost our income,” she said. “The landlord has offered a rent deferral but while we can pay we will, otherwise we will end up in thousands of pounds of debt over the next few months. Even with the deferral we’ll have to pay it back at some point anyway.“Nobody knows when we will be able to earn again, so we are stuck.&nbspWe have just got to pare everything back and keep our heads above water if we can. I have applied for UC however the first payment isn’t available until 13 May, and even then, I don’t know if it will be enough to keep paying our rent.”Ms Neate, who delivered&nbspa 43,000-strong petition to Downing Street on Thursday, calling on chancellor Rishi Sunak to take action, has said that “millions of renters will be in dire straits further down the line without more government support”.Last month, analysis by Shelter revealed that almost one in five private renters in England – an estimated 1.7 million adults – expect to lose their job in the next three months due to the crisis.More recently, research from the District Councils Network suggested that more than 486,242 households are spending over half their income on private rented housing.Communities secretary Robert Jenrick has said the government will ensure councils “have the resources that they need to carry out the absolutely critical functions that they are playing in our national response to coronavirus”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: help the hungry wembley stadium takeover food charity felix project
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Our appeal partner The Felix Project is providing food for the ventureWembley Stadium has opened its vast main kitchen to cook 140,000 meals a week for the hungry with produce provided by our Help the Hungry&nbspcampaign partner, The Felix Project.Chef Harry Lomas, culinary chief at the 90,000-seat venue, will lead an emergency cooking operation organised by Compassion London, a food charity founded by Leon Aarts in response to the coronavirus crisis.Six weeks ago, Mr Aarts and his volunteer chefs began cooking in a tiny kitchen at Staples Corner in&nbspLondon.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThree weeks later they moved to the kitchen at Saracens Rugby Club stadium in Barnet and now they will move again – to Wembley’s main kitchen, approximately the size of two tennis courts.It is a story of ordinary people pulling out all the stops to do extraordinary things to help the vulnerable. Mr Aarts, an activist, philanthropist and chef, said: “We have ramped up from 200 to 3,900 meals a day but the move to Wembley will allow us to gear up further to cook and deliver 20,000 meals a day – which is 140,000 meals a week.How to support our campaign“We already supply 15 hospitals, elderly care homes, community centres and homeless hostels. These organisations are trying to cope with unprecedented demand for food and they keep asking us for more. Our new kitchen will allow us to keep pace with rising hunger and need.”Compassion London operates seven days a week with 25 chefs and 200 volunteers who pack and deliver food to charities and families. The fresh, raw produce comes daily from The Felix Project, the biggest distributor of surplus food in London, which has quadrupled its deliveries since lockdown to 40 tonnes a day and supplies daily more than 100 charities, schools and community hubs like Compassion London.The Independent has pledged to raise £10m to help The Felix Project feed hungry people across the capital over the next three years – with £3.65m already donated since we launched our appeal on 27 March.The Wembley facility is being given to Compassion London free of charge, thanks to Wembley Stadium, its in-house caterer Delaware North and the stadium’s owner, the Football Association.Top restaurant chefs join forces to provide free meals for familiesPhoebe Waller-Bridge backs our appealOur appeal raises £3.5m as food crisis deepensHead chef Mr Lomas said: “Using an empty kitchen and bringing food together to feed vulnerable people and the NHS is fantastic. It’s a win-win situation.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailJon Sellins, operations director at Wembley, lauded Compassion London as “a passionate team of volunteers with a simple mission – to help others in this time of crisis”.Mr Aarts, who previously set up a similar kitchen in the Jungle Calais camp in response to the 2015 refugee crisis, founded Compassion London out of the same instinct, he said. “Our purpose is the principle of no one goes to bed hungry.”Follow this link to support, volunteer or donate to Compassion London.The Independent&nbspis encouraging readers to help groups that are trying to feed the hungry during the crisis – find out how you can help&nbsphere. Premium.Trade commissioner suggests&nbspBritain is planning to blame Covid-19 for Brexit 'fallout'The UK is showing “no real sign” of approaching Brexit trade talks with a plan to succeed during the coronavirus pandemic, the EU’s trade commissioner has said.Phil Hogan&nbsphas suggested the UK&nbspgovernment is planning&nbspto blame Covid-19 for “the fallout from Brexit” because it does not want negotiations to continue into 2021.He also warned that the government's current approach needed to change to avoid an “almighty blow to the UK economy later this year”, which could “spill over” to other countries, such as Ireland.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Despite the urgency and enormity of the negotiating challenge, I am afraid we are only making very slow progress in the Brexit negotiations,” Mr Hogan told the Irish broadcaster RTE.“There is no real sign that our British friends are approaching the negotiations with a plan to succeed.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus Podcast“I hope I am wrong, but I don't think so.”Brussels and the UK government are currently negotiating a trade agreement via video-conferencing, due to severe restrictions on movement introduced on both sides of the Channel to slow the spread of coronavirus.Ministers have&nbspinsisted the transition period will not be extended beyond 2020, despite&nbspunprecedented disruption to daily life due to the pandemic and officials on both sides admitting there has been little progress in the first two rounds of formal talks.The Scottish National Party (SNP) has called for an extension to the Brexit transition period until the end of 2022 due to the coronavirus crisis and urged Labour and other opposition parties to support them.&nbspMatt Hancock, the health secretary, claimed earlier this week that there was “absolutely no need” to extend the transition period.Mr Hogan insisted that the EU was “serious” about a deal and said the UK needed to outline further details about what it wanted&nbspto achieve.The trade commissioner added: “I think that the United Kingdom politicians and government have certainly decided that Covid is going to be blamed for all the fallout from Brexit.&nbspMy perception of it is they don't want to drag the negotiations out into 2021 because they can effectively blame Covid for story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'The leadership of the Labour Party was number one, fair or unfair'Sir Keir Starmer has said Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership of Labour was the “number one” issue that voters raised on the doorstep before the party’s disastrous election defeat in December.The new Labour leader also reiterated his criticisms of the party’s most recent manifesto for government, describing the radical document as an “overload” with “too much in it”.Sir Keir, who was hesitant to criticise his predecessor during the internal leadership election contest, said he visited over 40 constituencies during the winter election to speak with voters.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpeaking to the Financial Times, he said: “The topic of conversation was always what was coming up… anybody who knocks on doors knows a number of things came up. The leadership of the Labour Party was number one, fair or unfair.”Sir Keir, who campaigned for Labour to adopt a pro-EU stance and was largely sidelined by party strategists during the campaign, also said Brexit was another issue raised on the doorstep of voters.Starmer calls for 'national consensus' on lifting lockdownOn Labour’s strategy during the coronavirus pandemic, Sir Keir said his party needed to be “constructive” when criticising No 10’s failures, as he confirmed in a separate interview he would support another extension to the UK-wide lockdown.Pressed on the issue on the BBC’s Good Morning Scotland programme, he said he believed the restrictions should remain in place until “we are sure the infection rate has gone down”.Later today, Boris Johnson will decide whether to extend the lockdown by another three weeks, but is not expected to address the nation until Sunday evening where he will also set out the government’s next steps in the crisis and any restrictions that may be eased in the coming weeks.Sir Keir added: “I would be very surprised if the government doesn’t reimpose the lockdown when it comes up for review later on and we will support them in that. This is not about lifting the lockdown now, it’s about planning for the future.“Of course we want the number of infected cases to go down, we want the death toll to go down but we’ve got to also plan for the future and I’m convinced testing, tracing and isolating is going to have to be a part of any strategy fro the future.“But if that’s going to happen the planning needs to go in now because we need many many more tests than we’ve got already”.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: russia coronavirus doctors cases covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.News that&nbspthree critics of Russia’s&nbspcoronavirus response had plunged to the ground caused some&nbspto howl foul play. It’s likely the true circumstances are somewhat&nbspdifferent&nbsp— but no less horrific. Oliver Carroll reports from MoscowIn Russia, the news this week should have been about Covid-19 taking ever greater chunks out of the country. An unexpected surge in infections has, after all, made it the fifth-most affected nation on earth — with little sign of the crisis abating.Instead, headlines around the world have been dominated by a more unusual effect of the virus in Russia – a&nbspspree&nbspof frontline workers falling out of windows.In the course of eight days from 24 April to 2 May, three medics plunged to the ground. Two have already been buried by their colleagues one is fighting for his life in intensive care with a fractured skull. In all three cases, there is evidence of serious conflict with hospital authorities over the coronavirus response.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSome international media have used these tragedies to tempt&nbspreaders into the assumption that&nbspRussian medics are being shadowed by government hitmen. In doing so, they draw attention away from a far more likely reality, and one that is no less horrific.From conversations with friends and colleagues of the victims, The Independent&nbsphas pieced together a picture of medical staff working under intolerable strain. The victims were pinched at least two ways: inadequately protected while working face to face with an invisible killer and&nbsppushed to the brink by a management class petrified of losing status and privilege.Face to face with coronavirus on a Moscow Covid-19 wardRussia would not be alone in seeing its medical staff succumb to apparent suicide amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Across Europe and the United States, doctors, nurses, and ambulance staff have taken their lives as a direct result of the virus. Some were&nbspfearful after contracting the disease, and left suicide notes about their despair. Others feared infecting others.But in Russia, a cocktail of guilt, secrecy and scapegoating seems to be exacerbating the stresses and strains of working through the pandemic.Scapegoating seems to be the most obvious trigger for the first of the deaths on 24 April. Up until her untimely end, Natalya Lebedeva&nbspwas an experienced ambulance service manager working in Star City, the restricted cosmonaut training outpost fifteen miles east of Moscow. Lebedeva died after falling from the fifth floor of a hospital in southeast Moscow where she had been receiving treatment for Covid-19. She was 48.According to a colleague, bosses had placed Lebedeva in charge of hospitalising important Covid-19 patients from Star City. Unfortunately, she became infected in the process and unwittingly formed part of a chain of infections that saw almost two dozen people hospitalised. The colleague, who asked to remain anonymous, confirmed to The Independent that superiors had blamed Lebedeva for failing to contain the virus locally. This seems to have led her to take her own life.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastJust one day following Lebedeva’s apparent suicide, a second medic would fall five floors from a hospital window. Yelena Nepomnyashaya, 47, the acting head doctor at the veterans’ hospital in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, died from her injuries a week later.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailA source in the veterans’ hospital described the manager as an upbeat inidual who was well-liked by staff. But she was also reportedly&nbspuneasy with the local authority’s plans to use the hospital to fulfil a presidential quota for additional Covid-19 capacity. The hospital wasn’t yet ready for such a switch, Nepomnyashaya believed: it had only one ventilator and inadequate stocks of protective equipment. Right up to her death, the head doctor was pushing to have the equipment in place, the source said.There is some confusion as to what conversations took place between the hospital chief and Boris Nemik, the local health minister. The regional bureaucrat denies any contact was made. But&nbspThe Independent’s source insists otherwise: that a conference call took place shortly before Nepomnyashaya fell to her death.“Yelena wasn’t unstable or an obvious suicide risk, but god only knows&nbspthe threats and impossible demands that were made,” the source said. “The thing we all fear now is that her death will be written off as the suicide of an unhinged woman who could not cope.”The thing we all fear now is that Yelena’s death will be written off as the suicide of an unhinged woman who could not copeThe third incident, which took place a week later, is more enigmatic. Paramedic Alexander Shulepov, 37, fell from the first floor of a hospital while receiving treatment for Covid-19. He remains in intensive care with serious injuries including a fractured skull.Again, there are signs of a&nbspconflict with management over&nbspCovid-19. Just 10 days earlier, Shulepov recorded a video with fellow paramedic Alexander Kosyakin. In the widely shared clip, the two ambulance workers are seen complaining about lack of protective equipment and, in Shulepov’s case, allegedly being forced to work with an active coronavirus infection.Kosyakin was later summoned by police and cautioned about spreading “fake news” about Covid-19, a criminal offence under Russian law. Shulepov would in time&nbspretract the video, saying that he had recorded it in “an emotional state”.It is impossible to know what might have gone on in Shulepov’s mind or on the ward that caused him to fall out of a window. But foul play would on balance seem unlikely: a first-floor window is not the most effective way to do away with an opponent without leaving a trace. It will likely be many weeks, if ever, before we get clarity about the affair. Both relatives and colleagues said they had been asked not to comment while the investigation is ongoing.Dmitry Belyakov, chair of Russia’s independent ambulance workers’ union&nbspand a working paramedic, said he had no reason to doubt the three incidents were suicides or attempts. But even so, he could not accept the cause of their death was accidental.The system is not set up for people to work normally or honestly, and it provokes incidents such as thisInstead, Belyakov placed the blame firmly at the door of management. Bosses are struggling to cope with an upsurge in Covid-19 across the country, he suggested, and had prioritised relations with their superiors over the wellbeing of staff.“Managers don’t know what to do, so they have taken to scapegoating the middle-rung people,” he said. “Exhausted enough by the pandemic, they are throwing themselves out of windows.”Belyakov said many of his members had contacted him to complain about unrealistic demands and working without&nbspproper protective kit. As a rule, his members have little leverage over working conditions. Most ambulance workers in Moscow are not local, the union activist said, so are beholden to huge debts, rents and mortgage payments, alongside&nbspthe whims of managers. “No one has declared a state of emergency or cancelled repayments,” he added.Other medics&nbspsuggested that the Covid-19 pandemic had simply cast new light on an&nbspage-old problem.&nbspDeaths among medical staff had become more tragic because people were “paying attention,” said Alexei Erlikh, a consultant&nbspcardiologist and&nbsphead of intensive care at Moscow’s Hospital Number 29. “The system is not set up for people to work normally or honestly, and it provokes incidents such as this.”In the absence of official statistics, Erlikh is one of a group of doctors who have taken to compile a “memorial list” of colleagues who have fallen victim&nbspto Covid-19. The list, which includes four medics&nbspfrom neighbouring Belarus,&nbspcurrently stands at 113.&nbspLebedeva and Nepomnyashnaya&nbspstand&nbspat positions 57 and 68 respectively.The doctor said it was inevitable that more doctors, paramedics and nurses would take their lives as the pandemic widens its reach across Russia in the coming weeks and months. Moscow is one story, he said when the virus properly hits the regions, things are only likely to get uglier.“There you have lack of protective clothing and equipment on one hand, and lack of expertise and organisational capacity on another,” he said. “Add in the secrecy of provincial Russia as you move away from Moscow, and you have all the ingredients for a perfect storm.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: how long when uk lockdown end coronavirus
story: PLANS that will provide a road map out of lockdown will be announced this week by Boris Johnson.The Prime Minister, who ed to Downing Street on Sunday, April  after battling coronavirus, will address the nation this Sundayto explain how current restrictions will be lted.The Government once again reviewed the current lockdown measures on Thursday, May  - with Dominic Raab revealing it had been formally extended once again.But that further detailed would come from Boris Johnson on Sunday , with the Prime Minister saying in Wednesdays PMQs that he could change the lockdown measures as soon as Monday.In the lunchtime meeting in Commons, Mr Johnson said: We have to be sure that the data is going to support our ability to do this.But that data is coming in continuously over the next few days.We will wantwe possibly can, to get going with some of these measures on Monday.This is despite the UK now having the highest death toll in Europe.Upon histo Downing Street after fighting off Covid-, the PM said Britain was now past the peak of the virus and revealed an exit plan will be unveiled this week.He said: We will be setting out comprehensive plans to explain how we can get our economy moving, how we can get our children back to school, back into childcare, and how we can travel to work and make le in the workplace safe.During his speech, its expected that:However, its understood that in some areas of the country, the restrictions could be tightened rather than eased.Its part of a whack-a-mole strategy to tackle areas where infections spike.It could lead to even stricter restrictions being imposed on areas such as care homes, prisons or whole towns.Minister Michael Gove confirmed this approach on Sunday, May , telling the daily coronavirus briefing at No: “It is important that we make clear that any approach we take is staged.However, Mr Gove acknowledged that lockdown measures will have an impact on people’s “mental and emotional well-being” - as well as economic activity.Dominic Raab extended lockdown on April  despite reports that the UK is facing its worst economic slump in historyBut Mr Johnson says he believes Britain will come charging back once the lockdown is over.Emergency measures were first announced by Mr Johnson on March .The unprecedented step was put in place in an attempt to limit the spread of coronavirus.In a televised address, the Prime Minister announced police would have the power to fine peoplethey left their homes for non-essential reasons.He said people were allowed to leave their homes for the following reasons:May : Contract tracing app began its trial in the Isle of Wight - as UK overtook Italy to have highest death toll in Europe and second globally behind USA.May : It was reported that schools are to reopen at the start of next month, with Year  kids expected to be first to , followed by Year  and  pupils, while the five tests that need passing before lockdown could be lted were revealed.May : May Day protests around the world spark fears of a Covid- resurgence.April :  Johnson hosts his first briefing since his . Promises to reveal a road map on reopening next week.April : Dominic Raab revealed the combined number of fatalities from hospitals, care homes and the wider community for the first time.April : Hancock doubles down on the  criteria to lt lockdown, expands testing capacity to care homes to protect elderly and the over s with symptoms and workers that have to leave home to go to work and are showing symptoms.April : PM Boris Johnson ed to work with a speech outside Downing StreetApril : George Eustice, the Environment Secretary, hosted the briefing alongside Professor Stephen Powis, and spoke about the UKs food supply chain. George Eustice said panic buying has stopped and , food parcels have been deliveredApril : Priti Patel said criminals are trying to exploit and capitalise during the pandemic.Priti Patel said that despite crime overall being down, the most sophisticated criminals are seeking to exploit and capitalise on the coronavirus pandemic.April : Drones are set to deliver crucial Personal Protective Equipment and medical supplies in a new Government trial. Grant Shapps has announced the scheme would begin testing next week with crucial items being delivered to the Isle of Wight.April : Matt Hancock announced that up to , people will be offered home-testing kits to help track the spread of the outbreak.April : Social distancing is likely to be needed until a vaccine is available for Covid-, according to the chief medical officer for England, Chris Whitty.April : Human trials of a vaccine developed by Oxford University were announced and will start Thursday, April . Johnson started working again, making an official call to President Trump.April : Boris Johnson tells his cabinet he is concerned lting restrictions too soon could result in a “second peak” and result in another costly lockdown. This comes shortly after the lowest UK death toll in April is announced at . There is also a new therapy being used on critically ill patients and new vaccine trials could be finished by August.April : A government adviser brought some hope, saying the UK had probably passed the first coronavirus peak. However, there was bad news for pubs that could stay closed until Christmas. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson laid out plans for  weeks of online learning but wouldnt say when schools will re-open.April : Scientists draw up top-secret traffic light system to ease Britain out of lockdown, but ministers deny it.April : Police set new guidelines in a three-page document on what reasonable excuses are to leave the house.April : Dominic Raab officially states Britain will stay in lockdown for another three weeks into May.April : Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer has urged the Government to be transparent and publish its lockdown exit strategy.April : Dominic Raab said he “doesnt expect” any changes to be made to the lockdown this week, with SAGE expected to announce the results of their review before Thursday.April : Home Secretary Priti Patel said police would be given discretionary powers to make sure people were following social distancing rules.April : Easter Bank Holiday saw warm weather descend on the UK, with the Government urging people to stay at home and save lives.April : Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announces it is too soon to lt social distancing restrictions,  with SAGE to review the restrictions after Easter Monday.April : The Prime Minister is admitted to hospital for treatment, ten days after first displaying coronavirus symptoms on  March.April : Cops are told to tone down heavy-handed enforcement, after drones were used to spot people visiting beauty spots, and checkpoints were set up at some locationsMarch : Police get new powers, allowing them to fine Brits flouting lockdown rules £ - or £ for second-time offendersMarch : Boris Johnson announced a partial, three-week-long lockdown, telling us to stay at home to stop the spread of coronavirus. Certain businesses and venues were ordered to close, including pubs, hair and beauty salons, places of worship and campsitesPeople can drive to do a country walk but onlythe walk is longer than the drive, says new police guidance on the lockdown.It also states that you can move in with friendsyou fall out with your husband or we.The new guidance, which appears to contradict some cops’ interpretation of the law, also says people can exercise more than once a day as well as stop to rest or have lunch on a park bench provided you are on a “long” walk.Police are advising, however, that it is not reasonable to take a “short walk to a park bench, when the person remains seated for a much longer period” or drive for “a prolonged period with only brief exercise.”On May , we reported that lockdown fines could nearly double to £ for the first breach and then £, for repeat offenders.It comes after  fixed penalty notices were dished out by cops for consistent rule breakers in four weeks to April  in England and Wales.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. A letter from the Prime Minister landed on the doorsteps of  million households across the UK.In it, Mr Johnson urges people to stay at home, protect the NHS and save lives.His message follows a letter sent out by NHS England to those considered extremely vulnerable to contracting the virus.That letter warns recipients that because they have an underlying disease or health condition, they are more likely to be admitted to hospital.Theyve been told to avoid all face-to-face contact for at least twelve weeks, except from carers and healthcare workers.Italy was the first Western country to introduce widespread restrictions and has tightened them week by week, banning all but core activities, says Reuters.It signed an order on January  shutting down flights to and from China.In early March the country was the epicentre of Europes coronavirus outbreak, and thus quarantined million people in the countrys north to contain the killer bug.By March , any movement within Italy was banned, including across municipalities.On April , the lockdown was extended until May .On May , Italians flocked back to work as restrictions began to be lted.France went into lockdown on March  with police patrolling streets to ensure people only leave their homes for essential reasons.On April , President Emmanuel Macron increased the nationwide measures for another four weeks to May .On April , Spain announced changes to ease the coronavirus lockdown by allowing only OAPs out in the morning, and children and a parent in the afternoonsMeanwhile, in the US, each state is reacting in dferent ways to the pandemic - some have closed schools and businesses, but others have taken a weaker approach, including in Arkansas, where the governor said restaurants could continue operating,they chose.On May , sunbathers flocked to Central Park in New York and had to be reminded of social distancing rules.

title: journalists coronavirus pandemic lockdown save press
story: Nonetheless, there is one indisputable need this crisis has highlighted like no other - the value of journalism. British journalism, in particular.What’s stopping you right now from falling off your perch in fits of laughter  Well, the fact that you’re currently digesting a work of journalism.This probably means that it’s an act – let’s call it that for now – which you’re used to committing on a fairly regular basis.Let’s also assume then that much of the information you gather, store and share comes from such journalistic sources.It’s likely you frequently form opinions and make decisions based on this content you consume.In fact, think really hard for a moment and try and imagine an area of your le where you haven’t been guided in some form by journalism.Buying a house, investing your savings, choosing a school, picking a holiday, deciding which box to put your cross in when you go into a polling booth .If you’re honest with yourself, you tend to make most of those decisions after you’ve digested the array of journalism available to you. And let’s also admit, disregarded too.Some of it is opinion led, some is impartial. You might not agree with all of it, and sometimes you might get ruddy cross at a paper or commentator that doesn’t chime with your world view.But together, the many erse components of British journalism create something which is profoundly valuable.The Covid- pandemic has tested our society to the limit. In the midst of a national crisis, journalists have been putting their lives at risk to keep you informed.News outlets have faithfully broadcast public health announcements – but also held our political leaders to account.The Downing Street daily conference has become a household staple, with ministerial interrogation by the press corps regularly influencing government policy.Without such probing questions and front page splashes, would you have known about the dearth of PPE or the crisis in our care homes Journalism, from local to national level, has connected communities in a way that social networks can only dream of. We have celebrated triumph in the face of adversity – and also documented tributes from the tens of thousands who have lost loved ones.But now we come to the rub.With the country under lockdown, British journalism is facing the biggest threat in its storied history.For newspapers, sales have dramatically fallen. For broadcasters and online outlets, advertising has gone through the floor even whilst audience numbers have risen.Yes, journalism joins one of many industries in financial peril right now.The work of reporters should be held up to scrutiny like any other profession. But we also need to acknowledge the sacrices its practitioners are making to keep the public informed.Everything that journalism hands to you doesn’t come for free.I’m sure that when you think about this properly, in a way you might never have done before, it really is needed more than everWe have to safeguard journalism. It is far too important to discard because it isn’t worth contemplating what the world would look likequality journalism didn’t exist.I don’t need to urge you to buy a paper or take up an online subscription, but I want you to tell everyone you meet that our sector is under a very real and present threat.I am the CEO of the Journalists’ Charity. It was founded in  by Charles Dickens and a group of parliamentary reporters – naturally in a pub.Our core mission to this day remains the same: to bring aid to journalists and their dependents who have fallen on hard times.We are stepping up to the mark, helping those in need with emergency funding and practical and emotional support.It’s why we’ve launched a #supportjournalism campaign in print and on social media.For me, a lockdown without journalists would be unthinkable.That’s why the Journalists’ Charity is standing four-square behind our industry when it needs us most. But we also need you to do your bit too.The Journalists’ Charity has been helping journalists through tough times for more than  years. The charity is currently supporting iniduals from all sectors struggling from the impact of Coronavirus. title: joe wicks lockdown jamie oliver
story: RIGHT then, Joe Wicks. He’s just Jamie Oliver with a skipping rope, I assumed, before this wretched lockdown business began.A character we’ve all seen in our local park, with a pair of boxing gloves and a stopwatch, charging financial managers £ a haemorrhoid to do some sit-ups over by the ornamental lake.One of Britain’s ever-growing army of personal trainers who,he wasn’t bouncing around on YouTube every morning, would be clogging up Love Island or Ex On The Beach.That’s what I thought, anyway.Then the coronavirus hit, the local swimming pool shut, the man became a phenomenon and before I could come to my senses, Joe and his infernal timing device were beeping away in my living room, every morning, as I joined in his PE lesson. Inevitably, it didn’t last.First, Joe’s routine did me what I can only describe as “a mischief”.Then, one morning, aged , I caught sight of myself, in a picture frame, doing his “reverse frog shuffle” and thought: “Stuff this for type two diabetes. I’m out.”I’d got no closer to understanding Joe’s astonishing popularity, though, which is truly global.Over , people log in just to stare at his fairly spartan living room, every Monday to Friday.Hundreds of thousands more appear when Joe starts his  minutes of physical jerks.So, in an attempt to unlock the greatest mystery of the outbreak, I kept watching Joe and swtly came to the conclusion success was not linked to his presenting skills.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Because, for a host, he has a strangely distracted and chaotic air about him, with sessions regularly being interrupted by technical issues, forgetfulness and tiny daughter Indie, who charged in, dressed as Zog the dragon, on Friday.He’s not the greatest multitasker either, as Joe often demonstrates with the geography quiz he’s introduced to jolly things along.“What is the capital city of Moscow. . .   No. I mean Russia.”He also has to believe me when I tell him he’s not one of le’s natural comedians.“What’s the capital of Cuba  Fray Bentos. Nah, only joking.”The jokes need to go the same way as the viewers’ poems, in honour of Joe, which he was actually reading out loud, until modesty finally prevailed.Much safer ground is the “spot the dference” competition, which borders on insulting, when he’s merely placed his wall atlas upside down or swapped his electric guitar for a ukulele, but does hint at the drive, ambition and ego behind the man.One day he replaced the atlas with a picture of himself, the next with a picture of his “other house” in Los Angeles and suddenly the penny dropped.Joe’s loaded and his head is not just on its way to Hollywood, it’s already there, making movies and doing squat thrusts with Gwyneth and Brad.The weird thing is, in other presenters, soap actors or comedians, I’d roll my eyes at the folly.With Joe Wicks, I don’t. ’Cos I can’t help it, I quite like him.Part of that may be linked to his no-frills background and a level of personal generosity that’s way beyond most of us .But I like to think it’s got more to do with the fact that, at a time when other cynical, doom-mongering TV hosts are desperately trying to read the public mood, reinvent themselves and force their agenda on viewers, Joe Wicks is just doing what he’s always done. Sit-ups.He may not be Emily Maitlis , but he’s the irrepressible and lucky optimist telling us to get off our fat a***s when we need to hear it most.He’s temporarily indisposed at the moment, of course.A gammy arm means we Rosie is leading the workouts.But I was firmly of the opinion nothing and no one could ever stand in the way of world domination, until I tuned into Sunday night’s Diva On Lockdown and there was Gemma Collins trying to contort her mighty bulk into one of Joe’s squats while she bellowed: “I wonder how Joe Wicks would feelhe knew the GC was doing his workout ”Beaten, I’d imagine.He must never know.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.And her face is glued to the back of her head.So there will be hell to payit comes unstuck on The Real Marigold Hotel, where the only other one of the eight celebs who’s appeared looking as unearthly as Britt is former Dragons’ Den star Duncan Bannatyne, whose hair is now a “vibrant and colourful” shade of roast papaya orange. And will remain that way, until the monsoon breaks.It’s probably safe to say neither of them will be hanging around that long, though, or “retiring to India” any time soon.This is the fourth series of the BBC show and not one of the famous pensioners has given the place a second look yet.They have, however, all come home alive.So I wish the Beeb would count its lucky stars, cut the pretence, make Duncan pay for everyone’s holiday and let us all enjoy their discomfort, which is considerable and very entertaining.During the first episode: John “Nasty Nick” Altman proved as supple as Tower Bridge at his first ever yoga lesson.Paul Chuckle remained confined to barracks with the trots.Henry “Blowers” Blofeld rejected insect repellent on the grounds that: “Mosquitoes get p***edthey bite me.”And actress Susie Blake certainly didn’t hold back when the local foot doctor told her: “You have some unwanted growths.”“Yes, I have haemorrhoids.”Susie, too much inflammation.Jamie Redknapp: “We always used to turn up late but somehow we’d make it in time.Martin Keown: “Vieira was the best I ever played with. But Henry was a great player, so don’t make me choose between them.”Paul Merson: “The secret to working hard is to work hard.”ON one particularly fraught episode of her Channel  show, last week, Steph McGovern was forced to let a wasp out of her living room window, live on air.Probably halving her audience in the process.A day later it was announced the show itself was being released back into the wild, or as they put it “taking a break”.Credit for this development was being given to Steph’s long-suffering neighbours, who’d objected to the disruption the production had caused and may yet get a Bafta fellowship for their intervention.Truth be told, though, Steph’s “power hour of positivity” was more likely killed by worthiness, lack of content, technical issues and the host herself, who’s a rotten interviewer, kills every good joke stone dead, has the same set response to everythingand a terrible habit of asking exactly the wrong question.“Martin , what are you doing with all that toilet paper ” “Errr . . . ”There’s talk of a brave new dawn, in a shiny Leeds studio, later this year and when I last checked, author Marian Keyes was giving some pointed advice on how to become a good novelist: “Your first efforts will be woefully appalling. It’s like anything in le you want to be good at. Keep showing up.”Steph. Don’t.MORE now from Russell Grant’s “uncannily accurate”  predictions in December’s Mirror.“Scorpio — travel will be a great source of joy for you in April.”Yeah, April. How’d that work out for you Netflix thriller series Fauda. Channel ’s SAS: Who Dares Wins . Episode two of BBC’s Jewel Of Arabia .BBC repeating Bob Monkhouse: The Last Stand.And BBC Breakfast discovering that not only is he a war hero and charity giant, he’s a former Blankety Blank contestant as well.Cometh the hour, cometh Colonel Tom.Craig: “Arm.”Bradley Walsh: “What vowel precedes the name of more than ten dferent Apple products ”Becky: “C.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which word used to describe horses of a reddish brown colour is also a type of window ”Paul: “Velux.”RE: The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The name of what flightless bird is slang for someone who refuses to face facts ”Becky: “Kiwi.”You mock, but I shouted: “Diane Abbott.”Table, restaurant, postcode, country, Commonwealth of Nations and beyond that, his own gravitational field.Dumbest question was obviously: “Would you like dessert ”CHANNEL ’s When Will Lockdown End  The highlights.Professor Hugh Montgomery: “I don’t know.”Professor Graham Medley: “Anyone who tells you they know is lying.”Professor Peter Horby: “We just don’t know.”So in conclusion, try asking Russell Grant.RANDOM irritations: Have I Got News For You echoing to nothing but the sound of its own self-satisfied laughter.ITV numbskulls destroying Van Der Valk’s famous theme tune.Toxic hypocrite Frankie Boyle biting the Press hand that’s fed him far too well, by the looks of things.BBC’s Panorama failing to reveal every single interviewee on Has The Government Failed The NHS  was a left-wing activist.And ITV’s Joel Dommett making we Hannah the co-host of his Home Alone show.Which is a bit like Linda McCartney sharing lead vocals with Ringo. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
